sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for Conditional particles (values should be particles e.g. ʔin - ʔiḏa - inkān ... (as few values as possible meaning group allophones inkān and inčan would be together). .

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

cit.quote: If it were gold it would shine
ʔiza ṭiwwal w ma wfaytu ma ʔiddamtu lal-maḥal ma ndarit bass ma tins[ɛ]
If it takes a long time and you do not, you do not pay it, you do not present it to the place you made the vow for, do not forget (the vow).
If you (m.sg) go I go with you (m.sg).
law kään yääkul ʔaktar ma kään dəʕəf hēk
If he had eaten more he wouldnt have lost weight like this

wib:featureValueObservation.note: According to the author, the use of this is due to influence of sedentary speakers. (Younes 2013:45)
Rarely used
Used in poetry
These are considered by the author as K-Forms

cit.quote: and if I do not bring them?
if you come in the morning you will find me
in ma ḷagaṭṭ ha-ṛ-ṛaḅāḅah ugult,lamzaʕ ṛās-ak
if you don´t pick that ṛaḅāḅah and recite, I´ll cut your head off
when he dies, his sons will inherit
if you had come, we would have gone together
if I knew your name, I would have called you (by it)

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Used only by the most conservative speakers

cit.quote: in kānu islām aw masīḥiyye tagrīban kull-hum bi n-nisbe la l-qānūn mutasāwiyīn
whether they are Muslims or Christians, they are almost all equal before the law
if they had stayed, they would have killed them
iḏa l-kalb fāt əd-dār, əl-malāika mā bitfūt əl-bēt
if a dog comes into the house, the angels don"t come in

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Used only by the most conservative speakers

cit.quote: if the camel doesn"t come in (into the house), it´s because it´s yours
lawinno maʕā sayyāra... rrū(ḥ) ʕa sahra l-lēle
if he had a car, we'd be going to a party tonight
muš lissa ǧahəl walawinn-hum ʕa l-baṣāṭa
They weren´t ignorant even if they were living in a simple way
if what you say is going to be like what you do
ilkān gōlaḳ mā yṣīr zayy fiʕlaḳ, waḷḷāh la-gṭaʕ ṛāsak
if what you say is not going to be llike what you do, by God, I shall cut your head off
if you don´t have tobacco with you
if you have camels, they raid (you)
ʕamalak ḥayinfaʕak, inkānnu kwayyis ṛaḥ yinfaʕak
your actions will be of use to you
waḷḷah, w ilkān ilbint ʕāyza lwalad, biyšūfu huṃ biddhum mahiṛ gaddēh
by God, and if the girl wants the boy, they see how much dowry they want
but if it is a man, he says...
a'ḥuṭṭ ʕalēha zanzabīl, inkān widdha ṭaʕāyim zanzabīl
I add ginger if it (f.sg.) needs ginger spices
w ilkān mā ʕindna buʕṛān aṛṛaǧil ʕa ḏ̣hu'rah, w alḥuṛmah kabšat digīg, iw miḥḥa lugmit ʕaiyš ʕašān miḥḥa ʕyāl iṣġayyrīn iyṣaaḥūn f-aṭṭirīg

and if we do not have camels (for transport), the man (will carry his things) on his back, and the woman (will bring) a (large) spoonful of flour, and she will have a bite of bread with her, because she has small children with her who will cry on the way

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Ilkān can also appear in the form ilkān + suff, and kān can sometimes be conjugated

cit.quote: w izkānha bintiʕammah yaʕni, fīha ēh? taxfīḏ̣ išwayyih yaʕn-alfēn ṯalāṯah
and if she is his niece, that is,, there is what on it (i.e. the bridal price)? There is a bit of a reduction, like two or three thousand
if...someone is in love with someone (f.), has taken a liking on someone (f.)
if it has disappeared, we say "the sun has disappered"
if you are just going to sit uselessly in front of me

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The author attests also the use of the suffixed ink​ān: inkānnak aflast "if you have failed"

cit.quote: if he hasn´t pissed on your moustaches
w aʕṭiy lah kān widdih lah ǧnēh
and I give (it to) him, if he wants a pound for himself
lak ṣāḥib fi lʕIrīš ʕizīz ʕalák bitlaggiy ʕalíh
if you have a friend dear to you in alʕArīš, you go to him

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Inkān can be alsoused to introduce alternatives

cit.quote: inkān wiyyāh giršēn, yaʕni fīh ʕaṛabōn la lkalām
and if he has some money (lit. two piasters) with him, there is a down payment for the whole thing
if he is innocent, he will say innocent
ilkān iyǧāwbuw māšiy... lāzim iygūluw ạ̄
if they answer (saying) okay, they have to answer (saying) yes
izkān aḅūha yaʕni ṭayyib, mawǧūd yaʕni ʕa lḥayāh
if her father is well, still alive, that is

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The author attests also the use of the suffixed ink​ān: inkānnak ḏ̣uhur "if it is in the afternoon"

cit.quote: if it is on the camel
if he is, for instance, walking at daybreak
mā ʕilim yaʕniy biǧíy ṯāniy min nahār ib gawadih
if he hasn´t heard, that is, he comes on the following day with his animal for slaughter
ilkān ax̣ūk, ax̣ūk, w ilkān ax̣ūne, ax̣ūne
if he is your brother, he is your brother, if he is our brother, he is our brother
al-wiḥdāt law inhin ikbāṛ mag̣ḅūḷāt, amma muš ikbāṛ
Were the housing units big they would be acceptable, but they aren´t big
law gōta'rut l-agsa iblād w inti ʕarabi zayyak... kān mā maʕ šī maṛṛa, mā maʕ igrūš, taʕarif innu yuturkak rġīf al-xubz
If you were to go to the furthest country in the world, and you are Arab, if you had nothing at all, no money, you know that you would be given bread to eat

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Koine-form

cit.quote: if a guest comes from outside

wib:featureValueObservation.note: It is the most common conditional particle in the dialect of the Bani ʕAbbād

cit.quote: law raḥat la-ʕammān, ygūll-ak hāḏ̣i ṣalṭiyya
if she would go to Amman, one would tell you "she is from Salt"

wib:featureValueObservation.note: It is widely attested in the dialect

cit.quote: sin aḏ-ḏhab tišbah al-fattāš, ʔin ḏiḥkat brūg ʔana-ḏ̣anni
(She has) a golden tooth that looks like fireworks, if she smiles I think (it is) a flash of light

wib:featureValueObservation.note: It is very rare in the dialect of the Bani ʕAbbād

cit.quote: oh Bana, if you loved me

wib:featureValueObservation.note: It is can be considered as a vestigial feature; this only example was obtained by elicitation

cit.quote: iza ḥaka maʕik ḥaki bahdilī ʔimsaḥi fī l'arḍ
if he as much as talks to you, scold him (lit. wipe off the floor with him)’,
alla ysāmḥ-ak law talfanit kān iǧitl-ak ʕala ṭūl
God forgive you. If you had called I would have come to you immediately

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Realis conditional clause is introduced by īkūn, tkūn or hāga (kurdish).

cit.quote: (īkūn) təstaxbərni hawnək aṭyab kān mən hawne.
If you ask me, it was better there than here.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Realis conditional clause is introduced by īkūn, tkūn or hāga (kurdish).
Realis conditional clause is introduced by īkūn, tkūn or hāga (kurdish).

cit.quote: if you had brothers, they would help you.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The protasis in a syndetic realis conditional clause is introduced either by ənn or by lay(Lahdo 2009:183). ənn is also used for irealis.

cit.quote: əs-saḥ ḥäälkən ənn kā-ṣār mali trōḥu t-Təllo əmme təbqaw fī Ṣṭanbūl?
If your situation becomes better, will you go (backt) to Tillo?

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The protasis in a syndetic realis conditional clause is introduced either by ənn or by lay(Lahdo 2009:183).

cit.quote: lay ḍurumna mmēni ysīr malī də-nrō nəḅʔa fət-Təllo.
If our (economic) situation is getting better, we will go (back) and stay in Tillo.

cit.note: kā is also used for irealis.

cit.quote: If my son comes back safe, I will vow a feast for him.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Mainly, the perfective verb follows the particle, and /b-/ prefix is used extensively in the result phrase (El-Shorbagy 2009:76).

Mainly, the perfective verb follows the particle, and sometimes zero-verb, such as biddi) and the imperfective verb is used in the result clause in future using the prefix /h-/ or /b-/ (El-Shorbagy 2009:80).

Mainly, the imperfective verb follows the particle / lamma>/, and the imperfective verb is used in the result preceded by /b-/ prefix extensively. The perfictive verb is rarely used (El-Shorbagy 2009:85).
Zero-verb follows the conditional particle illi essentially; imperfective verb sometimes appears after the conditional particle (El-Shorbagy 2009:88).
For unreal conditions, law (irrealis) and lōla (negative irrealis) are used (Rosenhouse 2007).
iza appears to be used for real conditionals while law is used for irreal ones; in only appeared twice, with an irreal function (Belinkov 2014:59).
iza appears to be used for real conditionals while law is used for irreal ones; in only appeared twice, with an irreal function (Belinkov 2014:59).
mostly for realis
mostly for irrealis
only in proverbs and idioms
Deducted from example
Deduced from example
corresponds to in kān

cit.quote: kān inte ǧīt ames ana sirt maaʕk.
If you had come yesterday, I would have gone with you.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: only created for the gahawa
only created for the gahawa

cit.quote: Al yōm kan mā tunūm, nahagginak
Today, if you dont sleep, I will sprinkle water at you
If you want, we'll marry you off
kīku mort and it-tabīb il-ǧima l-oḥra, (kīku) diǧa fiʔt
if you had gone to the doctor last week, you would already be fit

cit.note: Maltese orthography: Kieku mort għand it-tabib il-ġimgħa l-oħra, kieku diġa fiqt

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle describes an irrealis conditional sentence

cit.quote: if we run we might catch the bus

cit.note: Maltese orthography: Jekk niġru jaf nilħqu tal-linja

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle describes a realis conditional sentence
Deduced from examples

cit.quote: If I had known I would have told you
If he comes tomorrow I'll see him

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deduced from examples

cit.quote: iḏa yábbi iyī wiyyāna, gūl lih yixābirni min gábil
if he wants to come with us, tell him to inform me beforehand
lo mṭarša l-xaṭṭ, la tigūl liha l-xabar
if she has sent the letter, don't tell her the news
in čān yiḥāčīni bil-luġa l-inglīziyya, mā afham š-yigūl
if he speaks to me in English, I don't understand what he says
ila timtiniʕ min it-tadxīn šway, bitšūf šiḥḥatik titḥassan
if you give up smoking for a bit, you'll see your health will improve
in ḥaṭṭēt li ʕaṭbat-ik, gaṭṭēt-ik baḥar!
If you put your cottom rag under my nose, I'll throw you overboard!

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: ila waṣṣal hna nkayd-ah, ila mā waṣṣal mā nkayd-ah
If it comes here, we'll record it; if it doesn't, we won't

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: in ḥaṭṭēt li ʕaṭbat-ik, gaṭṭēt-ik baḥar!
If you put your cottom rag under my nose, I'll throw you overboard!

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: iḏa ana ṣaḥḥēt, aʕṭī-h dīnār wāḥid, u iḏa ana mitt mā lih šay
If I get better, I'll give him a dinar; but if I die, he'll get nothing

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: in čān yaw bi l-inšūr, il-ʕalam maḥṭūt,ginna əhummə mistānsīn
If they came back with flags flying, with the standard hoisted, we said "they're happy"

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

This particle falls under Condition II: "these are clauses which express a 'hypothetical' condition, i.e. one which might possibly occur, but is presented as less likely to be fulfilled than an 'open' one (typically, in English, signaled by the use of a subjunctive verb), e.g. 'if he were to go, we would follow', or a condition which is plainly impossible, e.g.'if I were you, I wouldn't do that'. (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: lō ākil ḥašīs u gatt, mā yixālif, wi lā ākil ḥarām
If I eat grass and animal feed, it doesn't matter, just as long as I don't eat things obtained unlawfully (or 'If I were to eat grass.... it wouldn't matter...')
lō kān ṭēr mā yigʕad ʕala šaǧara hna
If he were a bird, he wouldn't alight on a tree here
hāda zōǧ-i lō darēt bih, mā axadt-ah
If I had known what husband of mine was like, I wouldn't have married him (Here, the fact is that the speaker had married this particular man)

wib:featureValueObservation.note: lō is associated with the speech of the less educated, and may also be used in Condition II

This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

This particle falls under Condition II: "these are clauses which express a 'hypothetical' condition, i.e. one which might possibly occur, but is presented as less likely to be fulfilled than an 'open' one (typically, in English, signaled by the use of a subjunctive verb), e.g. 'if he were to go, we would follow', or a condition which is plainly impossible, e.g.'if I were you, I wouldn't do that'. (Holes 2016:402)

This particle falls under Condition III: 'these are clauses which express a 'counterfactual' condition, i.e. an event which did not actually occur, so the event contingent on that condition could not have occurred either, .e.g. 'if he had gone (implied:́'but he didn't'), we would have followed (but we didn't)'. (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: lō ākil ḥašīs u gatt, mā yixālif, wi lā ākil ḥarām
If I eat grass and animal feed, it doesn't matter, just as long as I don't eat things obtained unlawfully (or 'If I were to eat grass.... it wouldn't matter...')
lō kān ṭēr mā yigʕad ʕala šaǧara hna
If he were a bird, he wouldn't alight on a tree here
hāda zōǧ-i lō darēt bih, mā axadt-ah
If I had known what husband of mine was like, I wouldn't have married him (Here, the fact is that the speaker had married this particular man)

wib:featureValueObservation.note: lō is associated with the speech of the less educated, and may also be used in Condition II

This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

This particle falls under Condition II: "these are clauses which express a 'hypothetical' condition, i.e. one which might possibly occur, but is presented as less likely to be fulfilled than an 'open' one (typically, in English, signaled by the use of a subjunctive verb), e.g. 'if he were to go, we would follow', or a condition which is plainly impossible, e.g.'if I were you, I wouldn't do that'. (Holes 2016:402)

This particle falls under Condition III: 'these are clauses which express a 'counterfactual' condition, i.e. an event which did not actually occur, so the event contingent on that condition could not have occurred either, .e.g. 'if he had gone (implied:́'but he didn't'), we would have followed (but we didn't)'. (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: in čān yaw bi l-inšūr, il-ʕalam maḥṭūt,ginna əhummə mistānsīn
If they came back with flags flying, with the standard hoisted, we said "they're happy"

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

This particle falls under Condition II: "these are clauses which express a 'hypothetical' condition, i.e. one which might possibly occur, but is presented as less likely to be fulfilled than an 'open' one (typically, in English, signaled by the use of a subjunctive verb), e.g. 'if he were to go, we would follow', or a condition which is plainly impossible, e.g.'if I were you, I wouldn't do that'. (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: in ḥaṭṭēt li ʕaṭbat-ik, gaṭṭēt-ik baḥar!
If you put your cottom rag under my nose, I'll throw you overboard!

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: You'll think he's a Bihari if you see him (or You'd think he was a Bihari if you saw him)

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Variants of lēn include ilēn, ilan, ilān, ila ʕēn, ila min

This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: If I say to him "give me", he hits me

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: amma inta šēx wi lā iʕtarafōbik, ana yiʕtarifūn bī, faqīr ṭarrār?!
If you're a sheikh and they pay no attention to you, are they going to pay any attention to me, a poor beggar?!

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle is sparsely used

This particle falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: If you work, you eat...if you don't work...

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle (or lack thereof) falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: If you work, you eat...if you don't work...

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This particle (or lack thereof) falls under Condition I: "these are clauses which express an 'open' condition, i.e. one which is capable of fulfillment in the present real world or some future possible world, e.g. 'if ('whenever') he goes, we (will) follow', or, when the condition occurs in a narrative describing a past world which was capable of fulfillment or was actually fulfilled at the time referred to, e.g. 'if (= 'whenever') he went, we would follow/followed'." (Holes 2016:402)

cit.quote: If you come, I shall greet you
If you go to the desert, you will see them

wib:featureValueObservation.note: law expressed as lō
lō is more sparse in Kuwait than in Bahrain

cit.quote: ana in ḥāz al-ḥarīb wana bn ḥāšim
if war breaks out, I am the son of Hashim

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deduced from examples

cit.quote: if he wishes to drink that cup

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deduced from examples

cit.quote: if you do not do this, you will be lost…
if we buy anything we wear it in turns
lo inn wāḥid liggā-lih ṭalab ʕala darbih, iwaṣṣilih
if one finds an errand along the way, he completes it

wib:featureValueObservation.note: lō seems to be reserved mostly for irrealis-type conditionals

cit.quote: if he has broken something he will mend it
if you are going to accompany me, welcome
if I see him, I shall kill him
if I see him, I shall kill him

wib:featureValueObservation.note: This is mostly used for realis-type conditionals
This is mostly used for irrealis-type conditionals

cit.quote: If I find it, it's normal!
kān širib-ti zayyə da, wallāhi ta-nbasit
If you drink like that, by God you enjoy

wib:featureValueObservation.note: law is less frequently used than kān/kām

cit.quote: if he had come I would have gone with him
iza kān ga kunta ruḥta maʕāhu
if he had come I would have gone with him
if he had come I would have gone with him
if he had come I would have gone with him
if he had come I would have gone with him
in fittu min qādi sallmū-l-i ʕalē
If you (PL.M) pass by from there, greet (PL.M) him from me!
If he provides me with help, I will rescue his son.
inčād ᵊtrīd xāṯir zād anṭī-k saṭəl.
If you (SG.M) want more yoghurt, I give you (SG.M) a (whole) bucket.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: very rarely used in this variety

cit.quote: wāḥad lē tiḏ̣āyag al-ʕašīre kull-he tgūm ᵊbsāgt-u.
If one has troubles, the whole tribe backs him.
eger hēne hīčiḏ ᵊnhazzat ʕaǧab Baraǧīk iš-ṣār bī-he?
If (the earth) trembled like this here, what has become of Birecik?
Si je conaissais ton nom, je t'aurais appelé par ton nom.
If you come, we will go together.
If we help you what would happen?
If she says a word, she goes after her.
If I am Abu Umar, open the door!
If he had seen it, he would have hidden it.
iḏa kān ənḥibbu naʕəmlu fuxxāṛ əmtāʕ əl-māʔ
If we want to make pottery for water.
ida tḥabbu śrāb əl-lāgmi yśəkkəṛ świyya yḥaṭṭū-l-u xmīra.
If you want that the date syrup makes drunk, you put a little bit of yeast on it.
w liḏā yuḏ̣rub əl-wāḥəd kān wagt illi huwwa ʕand əḏ̣-ḏ̣arūra.
Therefore, you only beat him if it is really necessary.
S'il frappé courez lui ouvrir la porte.
If they spend the night we will pitch up the small tent.
ʕanz kī tabda simḥa ydīru kammūn aswad.
If a goat is beautiful they put black cumin seed on her.
If he talks to you, do not answer him.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: also used with pronominal suffixes, e.g. kān-u

cit.quote: If I had listened to you, I would have benefited from you.
I will pay him if he asks me to.
He can become rich if he wants to.

Deduced from glossary.

cit.quote: ʔinkēn sēʕa waḥde inte batsīr, thabbuṭ ṯinayn ṯilēṯ dihdayh dihdayh
If you were to go at one o'clock you would sell two or three (bundles of lucerne) immediately.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: In conditionals the b-prefix can occurr. There, it marks a present or past action or an action without reference to an explicit time.

cit.quote: mumkin yuṭbuxūn kull yōm ṭabxa muʕayyina yaʕni mumkin xubәz wa-iḏa mā b-ysawwūn xubәz maṯalan ʕaṣīda.
They can cook something specific each day, it can be bread and if they don't make bread they make ʕaṣīda.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deduced from example.

cit.quote: baʕdēn iḏa kān il-xišba rāhiya u guwiyya itsinn fīh
If the ship was strong and powerful it would get through it
šariṭ iḏa xallaṣṭuh baʕtīk šagāk kāmil
I will give your full wage on condition that you finish it
šariṭ la xallaṣṭuh baʕtīk šagāk kāmil
I will give your full wage on condition that you finish it
iḏā ġarabat aš-šams lā yuǧūz an yigbar al-mayyit
if the sun has set it is not possible to bury the dead.
lā šayyib aš-šaybih gaddim lih ṣabiyih
when the man grows old, offer him a young girl
if you beat water it will not get hot
in yistarū riǧiʕū mā yistarūš aḥtabasū
if they (m.) can, they return; if they cannot they are imprisoned

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deduced from example.

cit.quote: Kān hī ʕandhā ġanam ʕand ahalhā, man ʕarrasat, yāt b-il-ġanam, u-xallathin bi-firīghā
If she has goats among her own family, when she marries, she brings the goats and puts them in her (new) household.
